huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION:
This unit is currently over objective by over 2,000 elk.  This hunt is intended to help reduce this elk herd. This unit is usually a hard unit to hunt due to the lack of hunting pressure on the adjacent Ute tribal lands.  In the past the Ute Tribe had cow elk tags for late season elk hunts, however, the tribe has not had any late season cow elk hunts on their lands for a number of years which means the elk that move onto the tribal lands can stay there with no hunting pressure all winter.  The majority of the elk on this unit move onto Tribal Lands and will probably stay there unless the weather allows them to drift back up onto the Forest Service lands.  Permit numbers were reduced this year to reduce hunting pressure and allow more elk to move back onto the public lands. 
 Hunters should be aware of the Ute tribal lands and learn the boundaries.  Public hunting is not permitted on tribal lands but hunting near the tribal boundary will be the best areas to hunt.  There are no CWMUs on this unit.  
The unit includes the High Uintas Wilderness area but the elk will not be anywhere near that high in elevation during this hunt.
Road access on the unit is limited to mostly canyon bottoms due to the steepness of the terrain.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather during this hunt can be cold and snowy with a mix of sunny days.  Be prepared for muddy or snowy road conditions.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 42.5~5000~7400~~~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.CURRENT_POP: Around 7500 elk  in Jan. 2015.  This herd is over objective by around 2,500 elk and has been increasing. The Division is obligated by law to manage this herd towards objective so large numbers of antlerless elk permits are currently being issued.  Increased antlerless harvest is needed.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Elk on this unit move down in elevation for the winter and they winter primarily on Ute tribal lands and on south facing slopes at lower elevation on the Forest Service lands. The elk move towards the tribal land boundary as soon as they get much hunting pressure starting in Oct. There is very little hunting pressure on the tribal lands so elk have learned to go there as soon as hunting pressure starts. By the time this huint starts there are very few elk, if any in the Wilderness Area.
Recommended areas in the South Slope, Yellowstone: There are numerous suggested areas to hunt on this unit. Locating elk on public lands will be the difficult part this year. The suggested areas to hunt include (starting on the west side of the unit: North Fork of the Duchesne- limited road access, but elk can usually be found scattered out to the east of the canyon Blind Stream - limited road access, tribal land down low Rock Creek - paved road access, steep areas Pigeon Water - popular area but hunters must be aware of tribal boundary Lake Fork/Moon Lake- paved road access, some private property along the paved road Yellowstone - need to be aware of tribal boundary 77 Flat/Burnt Mill- a little flatter area, be aware of tribal boundary, hunt along the tribal boundary Dry Gulch- usually has elk this time of year near the tribal boundary Uinta Canyon- tribal lands down low, Lower Pole Creek area has been good in recent years Farm Creek- will likely need to get away from roads to find the elk, has been a good area the last couple years Whiterocks Canyon - Whiterocks River is the eastern unit boundary, steep terrain, usually some elk in the rough canyons north of Farm Creek trail head area Private Lands areas that usually have elk during this hunt: Arcadia, north side of Tabiona, Talmage, Mtn. Home, Altonah, Bluebell, Neola all have elk that come down off of the tribal land and onto private property when there is enough snow. If it snows early there may be land owners willing to let the public hunt elk if they move onto their private lands.

huntMaster.NOTES:
Excludes tribal land
Please be aware that the DWR may be conducting aerial surveys or big game captures during the season dates of this hunt.
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: Voluntary: Hunters who obtain this permit are encouraged, but not required, to submit a harvest report. Report your harvest online or by calling 1-800-221-0659.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public lands are all Forest Service lands managed by the Ashley and Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forests.  This unit includes a large portion of the High Uintas Wilderness Area where all motor vehicles are prohibited.  This unit also includes large tracts of Ute tribal lands that are closed to non-tribal members.  The tribal lands are mostly the lower elevation sagebrush zone but in some areas they reach up into the aspen/conifer zone.  There is a large amount of private property on the unit too.  Most of the private property is below the tribal boundary but there are several parcels of private property in the canyon bottoms.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Little Montes Creek WMA north of Ballard and Kevin Conway WMA southeast of Myton.  Elk, bear and cougar are rarely found on these WMAs.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
All Campgrounds on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the forest. There are special restrictions on camping and campfires in certain areas within the Wilderness area. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites.
Ashley National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley
Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/uwcnf
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: The main access points for the High Uintas Wilderness include: Uinta Canyon Trailhead, West Fork of Whiterocks Trailhead, Chepeta Trailhead, Lake Fork Trailhead, Yellowstone/Swift Creek Trailhead, Jackson Park road, Dry Gulch road, Rock Creek Trailhead, North Fork of Duchesne Trailhead, and Grandview trailheads
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100,000 Kings Peak and Duchesne topo maps
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service. Maps can also be purchased online at:http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: The hunt unit does not include the Ute tribal lands.  There is a large tract of Ute tribal trust land that stretches east to west across the South Slope of the Uinta Mountains.  Road access across the tribal land is permitted only across the main access roads to the Forest.  All ATVs are prohibited on tribal Lands, they must be trailered on access roads across tribal Lands.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Duchesne, Summit, Uintah and Wasatch countiesâ€”Boundary begins at SR-87 and US-40 in Duchesne; north on SR-87 to SR-35; northwest on SR-35 to the Provo River; north along this river to North Fork Provo River; north along this river to SR-150; east and north on SR-150 to the Summit-Duchesne county line (summit of the Uinta Mountains) at Hayden Pass; east along the summit of the Uinta Mountains to the Dry Fork-Whiterocks drainage divide; south atop this divide to USFS Trail #025; southwest on this trail to Whiterocks Lake and the East Fork of the Whiterocks River; south along this river to the Whiterocks River; south along this river to the Uinta River; south along this river to the Duchesne River; west along this river to US-40 at Myton; west on US-40 to SR-87 in Duchesne. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Duchesne, Dutch John, Kings Peak, Provo, Salt Lake City, Vernal. Boundary questions? Call the Vernal office, 435-781-9453.
